page_analysis.text_content:
Contextual garage placement

Contextual garage placement applies if, and only if, there is a predominant neighborhood pattern.

How to determine if contextual garage placement applies (using Fig 32 below as an example)

Note:
• If block is more than 600' long, consider only lots within 600' or the 10 lots closest to the subject lot
• If subject lot is a corner lot, consider the pattern on the street that the subject garage faces

Exclude the following types of lots:
• Flag lot (C)
• Multi-family use of 3+ units (G)
• Corner lots (A & H)

The remaining lots including the subject lot, contribute to the determination.

Note:
• If block more than 600' long, consider only lots within 600' or 10 closest lots.
• If subject lot is a corner lot, consider the pattern on the street that the garage faces

Divide the remaining lots, including the subject lot, into two categories:

1. Front-half pattern lots
• lots with garage in front half of the lot (F)

2. Rear-half pattern lots
• lots with garage in the rear half of the lot (B & D) and
• lots with no garage (E) (counts as a rear-pattern lot)

Determine which pattern category is predominant i.e., into which category more than half of the lots fall.

Front half

Rear half

The contextual-garage-placement regulation DOES apply. Projects on this block must place the garage in the rear half of the lot.

Fig 32 Example of a block on which the contextual garage placement regulation applies

visual_elements.description: Flowchart showing the process to determine if contextual garage placement applies. It starts with excluding certain lot types (Flag lot C, Multi-family use G, Corner lots A & H), then dividing remaining lots into Front-half pattern lots (lots with garage in front half of lot F) and Rear-half pattern lots (lots with garage in rear half B & D and lots with no garage E). The flowchart ends with a decision box stating that if the rear half pattern is predominant, the contextual garage placement regulation applies and garages must be placed in the rear half of the lot.

Illustration of a block with labeled lots A through H showing houses and garages. Lots A and H are marked with large X's indicating exclusion. Lot C is also crossed out. Lots B and D have garages in the rear half, Lot E has no garage, Lot F has a garage in the front half, and Lot G is marked as multi-family with multiple garages. The subject house is on lot F with a garage in the front half. This figure exemplifies the block on which the contextual garage placement regulation applies.

technical_specifications.parameter: Number of lots to consider if block is longer than 600 feet

subheadings: How to determine if contextual garage placement applies

additional_notes: The text is clear and legible with no visible handwritten annotations or stamps.
Page number 37 is located at the bottom right corner.
cross_references: Fig 32 referenced in the text as an example
